q: What are the symptoms of kidney stones?
a: Symptoms of kidney stones can include pain in the side of your abdomen, severe pain that comes and goes, feeling sick or vomiting.

q: When should I seek urgent medical help for kidney stones?
a: You should contact a GP or NHS 111 immediately if you are experiencing severe pain, have a high temperature, have an episode of shivering or shaking, or have blood in your urine.

q: What causes kidney stones?
a: Kidney stones can form when waste products in the blood form crystals that collect inside the kidneys, which can happen if you do not drink enough fluids, are taking certain medications, or have a medical condition that raises the levels of certain substances in your urine.

q: How are kidney stones treated and prevented?
a: Most kidney stones can be passed in your urine and may be treated at home with medication. Larger stones may require surgery. To prevent kidney stones, it is important to drink plenty of water and keep your urine pale in color.

q: What are the functions of the kidneys?
a: The kidneys remove waste products from the blood, clean the blood, and transfer the clean blood back into the body. Waste products are passed out of the body through urine.

q: Can small kidney stones be passed without any discomfort?
a: Yes, small kidney stones are usually passed out without causing discomfort.

q: What is the estimated recurrence rate of kidney stones?
a: It is estimated that up to half of all people who have had kidney stones will experience them again within the next 5 years.

q: What is the size of the kidneys?
a: The kidneys are approximately 10cm (4 inches) in length and are bean-shaped organs located on either side of the spine in the back of the abdomen.

q: Is surgery sometimes required to remove kidney stones?
a: Yes, larger kidney stones may need to be broken up or removed with surgery.

q: Is drinking plenty of water important in preventing kidney stones?
a: Yes, maintaining good hydration by drinking plenty of water is important in preventing the formation of kidney stones.

a: Symptoms of kidney stones include pain in the side of the abdomen, severe pain that comes and goes, feeling sick or vomiting.

q: When should I seek urgent medical help for kidney stones?
a: You should contact a GP or NHS 111 immediately if you experience severe pain, have a high temperature, have an episode of shivering or shaking, or have blood in your urine.

q: What causes kidney stones?
a: Kidney stones can form when waste products in the blood collect and form crystals in the kidneys. This is more likely to happen if you don't drink enough fluids, are taking certain medications, or have a medical condition that raises the levels of certain substances in your urine.

q: How are kidney stones treated and prevented?
a: Most kidney stones can be passed in your pee and treated at home with medication. However, larger stones may require breaking up or surgical removal. To prevent kidney stones, it's important to drink plenty of water and keep your urine pale in color.

q: What are the kidneys?
a: The kidneys are two bean-shaped organs located at the back of the abdomen on either side of the spine. They remove waste products from the blood and pass them out of the body when you urinate.

q: How common are kidney stones?
a: Kidney stones are quite common, affecting more than 1 in 10 people. They can develop in one or both kidneys and most often affect people aged 30 to 60.

q: Can small kidney stones be passed without discomfort?
a: Yes, small kidney stones are usually passed out in the urine without causing any discomfort.

q: Will I experience kidney stones again after having them once?
a: It's estimated that up to half of all people who have had kidney stones will experience them again within the following 5 years.

q: What can happen if kidney stones are left untreated?
a: If left untreated, kidney stones can be extremely painful and may lead to kidney infections or the kidneys not functioning properly.

q: Is surgery always required to remove kidney stones?
a: Surgery may be required to remove larger kidney stones, but most kidney stones can be passed in the urine or treated with medications at home.
